description: {"blocks":[{"key":"2magt","text":"This protocol is designed for extracting DNA from individual invertebrates for metabarcoding to detect and identify ecosystem service and disservice providers and their interactions. The reagents and methods proposed offer a cost effective and high-throughput method for molecular analyses of individual invertebrates using standard lab equipment. Where specialist equipment us used, attempts are made to suggest low-cost alternatives.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
ethics_statement: {"blocks":[{"key":"5trss","text":"Check national and institutional policies for insect research. Follow best practice guidelines and stay up to date with the latest developments in insect welfare (e.g., through the Insect Welfare Research Society). Only kill as many invertebrates as is necessary, and always do so as humanely as possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1ul6r","text":"Select suitable sites and locations for insect sampling. This protocol is based on hand-collected foliar and flower visitor invertebrates, but other collection methods are viable; be wary of cross-contamination and surface DNA though, and consider surface sterilisation accordingly. Consider how systematic the study needs to be and the various constraints imposed on the data by the study design.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4pro9","text":"Add 200 μL of the supernatant from STEP 10 into each well containing Protein Denaturation Buffer and ethanol. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1jtj6","text":"Carefully move the spin column plate to a new 0.5 mL DNA collection plate.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fv7s","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3dhku","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5i14a","text":"The liquid level following the final wash will be close to the base of the spin column, so take care not to let it touch to prevent ethanol transfer to the soon-to-be eluted DNA.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6jitj","text":"Add 200 μL Elution Buffer directly to the silica membrane and leave it at room temperature for 5 minutes, covering with a breathable seal.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bnesb","text":"Following collection, store insects in sterile tubes. For flower visitors, store insects dry and consider killing them with ethyl acetate on a cotton ball; for other insects, storage in 100 % ethanol may be ideal. Kill invertebrates as humanely as possible. Freezing is widely considered to be among the optimal methods.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9askt","text":"Two protocols are presented below, which simply differ in whether samples are ground or surface-washed. For herbivorous insects, we recommend grinding to facilitate analysis of internal DNA (either consumed plants or parasitoids). For flower visitors, we recommend surface washing (exactly the same protocol, but without ball bearings during the grinding step). This still facilitates analysis of DNA from the insect itself, but also pollen on the surface of the insect. These protocols could both be used for a wider range of potential applications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ukut","text":"Grind the samples in a tissue grinder/homogeniser/lyser at 1750 RPM for 1 minute.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5h40n","text":"Prepare Kingfisher Apex reagent plates as below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"61o1a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9sbgf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8dcac","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c1i80","text":"The Kingfisher Apex is ideal for automated high-throughput extraction of DNA, but will not always be available. In that case, rather than transferring beads between plates, remove the supernatant and replace it with the next reagent, as described for normalisation below.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8sqp8","text":"For ease, if able to use a 96-well pipette, consider creating a \"primer plate\" containing both PCR primers for each well at 5 µM concentration; this is especially effective when using multiple plates. For   reaction volumes, this will subsequently involve adding    hot-start Taq polymerase and water mastermix (described in the step above) to each well, followed by    of each primer mix to its corresponding well. It is possible to use this strategy with a multichannel pipette, but the next suggestion may be easier. Ensure that the temperature regime matches the enzyme used (including any heat activation for hot-start Taq) and that the annealing temperature matches the PCR primers used.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d448","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fs7pg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dgnah","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4s617","text":"Given differences between labs and samples, and inaccuracies in temperature calibration, considering running a temperature gradient PCR with known samples to check the specificity of your PCR primers. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ffc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sq28","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bp2nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0hfb","text":"If the PCRs were replicated (i.e., each sample run multiple times for each PCR primer pair used), these can be merged together into one plate at this point, or carried forward separately. Keeping the replicates separate increases the number of libraries to prepare and sequence later, but better facilitates inconsistencies between samples. To merge triplicates, assuming use of   reaction volumes, pipette   from each well of two of the three plates into the corresponding well of the third. Briefly centrifuge the merged plate to move the oil to the top of the product again.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":379,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":407,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"djkv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3g8i4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ocpj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e7ft1","text":"Equalisation is more effective than normalisation, but requires amplicon concentration data. Both can be time and labour intensive though, so can be skipped if time restricted for large-scale projects, although at the expense of data recovery and evenness.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"10","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"8","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5jctp","text":"To avoid pipetting oil from the oil-sealed PCR products, plunge the pipette to the first stop and fully insert the pipette tip into the bottom of the well, then release sharply. The PCR product will be taken up quickly, whereas the relatively viscous oil will be taken up slowly, thus being outcompeted by the PCR product.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b4as7","text":"Decide how samples will be distributed across plates (but don't distribute the DNA yet). Consider including a negative control in each row and column to detect any contaminants in each tagged forward and reverse primer. Among these wells, include any DNA extraction negative controls. Include positive controls (ideally mixed samples of species not found in the same study system), perhaps one adjacent to negative controls and the other adjacent only to samples (but both on separate rows and columns). {"blocks":[{"key":"b4as7","text":"Decide how samples will be distributed across plates (but don't distribute the DNA yet). Consider including a negative control in each row and column to detect any contaminants in each tagged forward and reverse primer. Among these wells, include any DNA extraction negative controls. Include positive controls (ideally mixed samples of species not found in the same study system), perhaps one adjacent to negative controls and the other adjacent only to samples (but both on separate rows and columns). {"blocks":[{"key":"8sqp8","text":"For ease, if able to use a 96-well pipette, consider creating a \"primer plate\" containing both PCR primers for each well at 5 µM concentration; this is especially effective when using multiple plates. {"blocks":[{"key":"6ffc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sq28","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bp2nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0hfb","text":"If the PCRs were replicated (i.e., each sample run multiple times for each PCR primer pair used), these can be merged together into one plate at this point, or carried forward separately. Briefly centrifuge the merged plate to move the oil to the top of the product again.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":379,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":407,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"djkv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3g8i4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4ocpj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e7ft1","text":"Equalisation is more effective than normalisation, but requires amplicon concentration data.
